data.title: Phillips 66: Attractive As Geopolitical Tensions Surge
data.description:
Shares of Phillips 66 (PSX) have been a solid performer over the past year, gaining about 20% as the company has benefited from an improvement in the refining environment, even as its chemicals unit struggles with weak pricing dynamics. Beyond this, investments in its refining facilities have helped to reduce operating costs and improve results. I last covered shares in October when I rated the stock a “buy” given its operational improvement, and since then, shares have rallied 12%, justifying that rating. With updated financials and new geopolitical pressures, now is a good time to revisit shares.

Geopolitical Developments Are a Net Positive

Of course, whenever looking at the oil sector, geopolitics is an important consideration. Earlier this year, the US removed President Nicolas Maduro from Venezuela, which is a positive for the refining sector. Venezuela produces the cheaper, heavy crude that our refineries specialize in processing. Incremental flows from this country can provide a cheap fuel that will widen margins. Indeed, PSX is working to source crude directly from Venezuela to enhance margins. I view this geopolitical development as a modest positive.

Additionally, this weekend the US and Israel launched a coordinated military strike on Iran. This operation is still developing, and the final outcome is unknown. Given years of sanctions, the US & Iran have essentially no economic linkage, and Iran’s crude oil exports have been pressured. However, if this conflict spills out more broadly, it could disrupt wider Middle East supplies.

If such spillover occurs, this conflict risks disrupting oil supplies more than refined products, which could pressure margins. Offsetting this, the Administration could make releases from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to keep markets adequately supplied, especially as it likely will want to limit any inflationary impacts. Heightened geopolitical risk premiums may also widen crack spreads. All else equal, I expect a near-term pop in crack spreads, but I view the longer-term impacts as less clear.

As geopolitical tensions have ramped up, we have seen crack spreads widen, passing $30 (as a reminder, this measures how much refiners make turning oil into refined products like gasoline and diesel). In late 2024, cracks dropped into the mid-teens, which created a difficult operating environment for the sector given strong throughput. Then, over 2025, we saw crack spreads steadily improve until a weakening late in the year. They have come surging back and are now over $30. As a reminder, I view ~$25 as the long-term norm, so we are in a clearly favorable environment for the sector.

The initial crunch lower in spreads in November/December came as physical fundamentals weakened. As you can see below, gasoline inventories rose more than even the seasonal norm, going from unusually low to unusually high. In general, higher inventories should mean weaker pricing power and lower spreads. Importantly, inventories have stabilized as we approach the seasonal drawdown.

Still, it is notable how much crack spreads have outperformed in recent weeks, largely decoupling from the physical market. This speaks to how much geopolitical risk premium has been added. With potential outages in the Middle East, markets are essentially encouraging US refiners to increase throughput. This creates a very favorable near-term dynamic for PSX and peers. That said, if geopolitical risk fades, I would expect crack spreads to narrow again into the $20-25 area.

Operating Performance Has Improved

Now, turning to recent financial results, in the company’s fourth quarter, Phillips 66 earned $2.47, which beat estimates by $0.32. In its refining business, profits rose by ~25% sequentially to $542 million, thanks to a widening in margins to ~$12.50. This represented a solid 98% capture of market levels. It operated at 99% utilization in Q4. I expect utilization to tick down in Q1 into the lower 90% area as the company does seasonal maintenance activity, which temporarily reduces capacity. As you can see below, it has steadily improved utilization after investing in modernizing its facilities. While doing this, PSX has also reduced operating costs by about 15% to $6/barrel. These self-improvement efforts should structurally enhance margins.

Aside from its refining assets, PSX has developed an integrated set of midstream assets, providing takeaway capacity from major basins all the way to export markets. These cash flows are less cyclical and more fee-like in nature. They provide enough cash flow to fully cover their dividend and maintenance, with cash flow from other businesses supporting buybacks or M&A. NGL transportation and fractionation volumes each hit records, passing 1mbd, and management reiterates its goal of reaching $4.5 billion in run-rate midstream EBITDA by the end of 2027. Midstream EBITDA was a solid $952 million in Q4, or $3.8 billion annualized. Given ongoing growth projects, I view its 2027 target as very attainable.

PSX also has a chemicals unit that is a joint venture with Chevron (CVX). While PSX has premiere, low-cost assets in the US and Middle East, the sector has faced significant challenges from structural oversupply given weak industrial demand and increased Chinese capacity. I expect challenging conditions to persist, and we need to see more supply cuts, especially from high-cost operators in Europe. The unit made just $19 million in Q4, down from $72 million last year. For the full year, profits fell by $500 million to $329 million.

I expect the chemicals environment to be equally bad in 2026, though if housing activity improves by late in the year, that can provide a floor. Ongoing supply cuts should eventually restore pricing power, but this is a very drawn-out process. In the longer term, I believe PSX should consider divesting the unit, as I see little operational synergies, especially with the midstream business growing and providing more diversification to cash flow. That said, I do not view such an action as imminent. Given the significant macro pressures, valuation in the chemical sector is depressed, and PSX would be best to wait for a cyclical turn before considering strategic alternatives.

Shares Remain Attractive

During the fourth quarter, PSX generated $2.8 billion of operating cash flow, aided by working capital improvements. This enabled the company to reduce debt by $2 billion, ending the year at $19.7 billion. PSX is carrying 38% net debt to capital, which is a bit more than I like to see. The company aims to get net debt down by about $3 billion over the next two years.

I view this as attainable so long as crack spreads average over $23, though it will limit buybacks in the near term. During Q4, it repurchased $274 million of stock. Thanks to buybacks, its share count is down about 1.7% from last year; I expect slightly more buybacks this year. In February, Phillips 66 increased its dividend by 6%, and shares now offer a 3.3% dividend yield. I view its dividend as secure

Overall, PSX is performing well. Its investments in refining modernization are paying off, and midstream continues to grow. Beyond this, the heightened geopolitical tensions are likely to be positive for refiners and PSX given its US-centric asset base. Back in December, I was targeting $12 of 2026 EPS and $16+ in 2027. I still view this as the central case, especially with crack spreads widening in the near term. At ~9.5x 2027 earnings, I view PSX as attractive still, though there is less upside than a few months ago. I expect shares to push to the $165-$170 area, and PSX also can help provide diversity in portfolios amid geopolitical tensions. With 8-10% upside plus a secure dividend, I remain a buy on Phillips 66.

data.title: AVLV: A Value ETF With A Distinct Sector Mix
data.description:
The Avantis US Large Cap Value ETF (AVLV) is among the funds following value-oriented strategies, but with additional profitability screens that give it a more balanced portfolio, blending industrials, consumer discretionary, financial services, and technology. While the fund has still seen higher volatility than peers, its sector mix shifts since my last review in late 2024 have reduced cyclical exposure, while a heavier stance in technology is consistent with its quality, given above-average profitability in the sector. In my view, this makes AVLV better positioned going forward, as the fund is likely to continue to outperform more conservative value ETFs in a risk-on environment, given its balanced sector mix, while its disciplined valuation is expected to limit downside risk somewhat, despite relatively high historical drawdowns. The next sections will detail the fund’s holdings and compare valuation, performance, and volatility with value peers and the broader equity market.

ETF Description & Highlights

AVLV is an actively managed ETF that seeks exposure to companies that exhibit above-average profitability and value characteristics, without tracking any specific index.

The stock selection process relies on portfolio managers’ research to identify companies that meet the fund’s strategy, primarily among the 1000 largest U.S. companies. To achieve this, portfolio managers take into consideration value indicators, especially book-to-price ratios, while profitability is measured through adjusted cash from operations to book, among other metrics. Once a company is selected for inclusion in the fund, it is weighted according to its market capitalization, plus a factor relative to its value and profitability metrics, so that constituents that offer more compelling metrics are overweight in the portfolio.

As of February 21, AVLV had nearly $10.6 billion under management, invested in 261 stocks, with an average market capitalization of $111.8 billion. Although the fund has a primary focus on larger companies, the reality is that large and mega caps make up only 32.6% and 18.9% of the portfolio, while mid caps account for 35.2% and small caps 13.2%. This reflects a well-balanced market cap distribution when compared to the Russell 1000, a mid and large cap benchmark, where large and mega caps represent over 70% of the index, versus nearly AVLV’s nearly 51%. It is also worth noting that the fund had a more pronounced mid-cap bias in October 2024, as the representation of this category was 40.5% at that time compared to 35.2% now. This gap is not large, to be sure, but it suggests a shift toward large caps, where valuations are admittedly above the broader market but profitability is generally higher than in smaller companies.

AVLV’s top ten holdings are Micron (3.26%), Exxon Mobil (3.20%), Meta (2.91%), Apple (2.78%), Caterpillar (2.68%), Amazon (2.51%), Lam Research (2.49%), Merck (2.31%), JPMorgan Chase (2.13%), and Costco (2.07%). Together, these positions account for roughly 26% of total assets, highlighting a less concentrated profile compared to the Russell 1000’s 34%, and a relatively diversified sector mix, spanning tech-driven segments, energy, industrials, healthcare, and financial services.

The table below shows a list of six value-oriented ETFs that will be referred to as the peer group for AVLV in this analysis. The first and the largest fund is the Vanguard Value Index Fund ETF (VTV), with roughly $150 billion in assets. VTV tracks the CRSP US Large Cap Value Index using a market-cap weighting approach. Next is the iShares Russell 1000 Value ETF (IWD), which follows an index that is the value version of the Russell 1000, and also applies a market-cap-weighted design. The SPDR Portfolio S&P 500 Value ETF (SPYV) selects stocks from the S&P 500 with attractive valuations and weights them by float-adjusted market cap. The Schwab U.S. Large-Cap Value ETF (SCHV) tracks the Dow Jones U.S. Large-Cap Value Total Stock Market Index, also following a capitalization-weighted structure. Meanwhile, the Vanguard Mega Cap Value ETF (MGV) focuses on the U.S. larger companies, with a heavy concentration in large (74%) and mega caps (18%). Finally, the Invesco S&P 500® Pure Value ETF (RPV) favors stocks with strong value characteristics and applies a weighting methodology that reflects this stricter investment strategy, giving more weight to companies offering more compelling value.

From a sector allocation perspective, AVLV’s largest exposures are to industrials (16.4%) and consumer discretionary (16.2%), two areas that are not typically the most value-oriented. A second tier includes financial services (15.0%), technology (14.2%), and energy (12.9%). Further down, communication services (9.1%), consumer staples (7.9%), and healthcare (6.2%) are still relevant sectors, while the fund holds marginal positions in basic materials (1.8%), utilities (0.3%), and real estate (0.1%). Although there have been only relatively small changes in the fund’s exposure to the largest sectors compared to late 2024, holdings in technology and healthcare have increased somewhat, while the allocation to financial services, basic materials, and energy has decreased by the 1.5% to 3.0%. This suggests a slight rotation away from interest rate and commodity prices sensitive areas, while the increased weight in technology points to a more balanced value-growth profile, as this sector is typically a high-growth segment.

Relative to the Russell 1000, though, AVLV remains most overweight in energy (+9.5%), followed by industrials (+6.8%) and consumer discretionary (+5.9%), while it is underweight in technology (-17.8%) and healthcare (-3.5%), despite the increased allocation to these sectors now.

Breaking down AVLV’s holdings across its largest sectors, we see that in industrials, the fund owns over 40 stocks, led by railroads, through Union Pacific and CSX, while it is also overweight in logistics with positions in FedEx, UPS, and Expeditors. The fund also holds heavy equipment makers Caterpillar and Deere, along with positions in airline operators like Delta and United Airlines.

In consumer discretionary, the fund is again broadly diversified, holding more than 40 companies. The largest position by far is Amazon, while the fund also leans into the travel and leisure segment via cruise operators Royal Caribbean and Carnival, as well as holdings in the casino and resort industry through Las Vegas Sands. The fund also owns off-price retailers TJX and Burlington, and automakers General Motors and Ford, while small positions in specialty retailers Ulta Beauty, Best Buy, and Dick’s Sporting Goods round out the fund’s exposure to the sector.

Beyond these top three sectors, where the allocation is fairly diversified, AVLV still holds relevant positions in other sectors, mostly with a much more concentrated exposure. These include technology, where the fund’s holdings are Apple, Micron, Lam Research, Applied Materials, and NVIDIA, along with key names in energy (Exxon and ConocoPhillips), communications services (Meta, Alphabet, Verizon, and AT&T) (1.50%), healthcare (Merck and Gilead), and staples (Costco).

Given AVLV’s strategy centered on value and profitability, the portfolio has suffered only modest rotation since late 2024, despite a few changes since then, such as increased allocation to companies like Alphabet, Amazon, Micron, Merck, and American Express, offset by divestiture from Chevron, Walmart, Qualcomm, and Wells Fargo. Still, such rotations are pretty much in line with an actively managed philosophy. That said, I believe that the high profitability usually seen in big tech names is expected to serve as an anchor to keep those names in the portfolio for the foreseeable future. On the other hand, margin pressures in more cyclical segments like energy, or even rate-sensitive areas like financial services, may drive potential changes from here, which would be in line with what we have already seen over the past year or so.

AVLV is overweight in consumer discretionary (+8.4%), communication services (+4.4%), and technology (+2.3%) relative to the peer group of value ETFs. Much of that is a byproduct of the fund's large allocation to a few big tech names, such as Meta, Apple, and Amazon. The fund also overweights industrials and energy, which gives it a more cyclical exposure. On the other hand, AVLV is underweight in typical value sectors, such as healthcare (-8.3%), financial services (-5.2%), utilities (-3.9%), and consumer staples (-2.7%), as peers favor these sectors, aiming to drive their average valuation lower than the broader market. As a result, AVLV has only a moderate sector correlation in the 0.50-0.70 range with most peers. At the same time, AVLV’s sector correlation with RPV (0.29) is arguably low, driven by RPV’s stronger value screens, leading to limited exposure to technology (2.2%), along with heavier exposure to healthcare (17.0%) and consumer staples (15.3%), amplifying AVLV’s modest stance in these two areas. From here, given the low stock rotation across these funds, as we will see later, I do not see a drastic change in this picture over the coming quarters, unless there is a sharp reset in the overall market valuation, which would create new opportunistic allocations for funds seeking to maximize value in their portfolios.

Attractive Valuation

AVLV’s 16.6x P/E represents roughly a 24% discount to the Russell 1000’s 22.0x. The gap is in large part driven by a sector mix that underweights a high-multiple sector like technology and has overweight positions in value areas, such as energy and consumer staples. Another core driver stems from lower valuation multiples in virtually all sectors, with discounts of over 30% in consumer discretionary, healthcare, and financial services. At the individual stock level, core contributions include Verizon (8.6x P/E), General Motors (7.9x), Merck (11.9x), and Allstate (7.0x), all trading well below the broader market average.

The fund trails in growth. Its historical earnings growth of 4.1% falls short of the Russell 1000’s 7.9%, and its sales growth of 5.9% is also below the benchmark’s 6.9%. This softer growth profile is largely tied to sector positioning, which, much like in the valuation analysis, underweights a high-growth area like technology. In addition, positions in consumer discretionary and industrials are also a drag, due to a much lower growth profile than in the Russell 1000. Overweight positions in companies in these sectors, including UPS and Las Vegas Sands, which have seen slow-to-negative growth, help explain the fund’s softer growth profile.

AVLV shows relatively strong profitability; However, it is not as high as the Russell 1000. Its EBITDA margin (28.3%) is about 2.3 percentage points lower than the index’s 30.6%, and the fund’s ROE (34.5%) also lags the benchmark’s 48.2% by roughly 13.7 points. AVLV’s underweight exposure to the high margins usually seen in technology does not help, of course. In addition, there is a negative contribution from lower margins in consumer staples and financial services relative to the Russell 1000. Shares of Costco (EBITDA margin 4.7% and ROE 30.3%) and Progressive (EBITDA margin 16.5% and ROE 34.2%) are good examples of a few individual holdings that contribute to lower margins compared to elevated metrics seen in the Russell 1000, thanks to the index’s heavy weights in high-margin big tech companies.

Although AVLV does not exhibit a pronounced tilt toward sectors like financial services and consumer staples, its P/E remains just below most peers. This is at least in part explained by overweight exposure to energy, another typical value sector, along with stock picking across most sectors with a low P/E profile, as highlighted in the previous sections. Meanwhile, the only fund trading at a deep discount to AVLV is RPV (11.2x P/E), driven by a very limited position in technology and a heavy exposure to small and mid caps, two categories that usually trade at a discount to large and mega caps, which together account for over 85% of the fund.

With all peers trading at a large discount to the broader market, it is fair to say that AVLV and the peer group continue to show more reasonable valuations in a market that has seen P/Es ratios above the historical average. That said, given AVLV’s modest turnover, I see the fund continuing to trade at a reasonable level and at a significant discount to the benchmark, unless a shift in sentiment leads to multiple compression in sectors like technology and consumer discretionary. If that were to happen, though, I would not be surprised to see AVLV increasing exposure to big tech names, as lower valuation multiples and consistent above-average profitability would make these companies more appealing to the fund.

Outperforming Peers

With its inception in September 2021, AVLV is still a relatively new fund. However, it has already gone through different market environments, ranging from a steep selloff in 2022, due to rising interest rates, to a strong bull market in the following years, fueled by AI prospects. Overall, as expected for a value-oriented fund, it held up much better than the Russell 1000 in 2022, but it lagged in the bullish years of 2024 and 2025, due to its more conservative exposure. It is also worth noting that it is doing very well year to date, with double-digit returns, while the Russell 1000 gained only 1.3%. Still, AVLV’s 3-year total returns of 19.3% have not kept pace with the benchmark’s 21.5%, as the overall market has been predominantly in a bullish mode during this period. AVLV has outperformed its peers, though, thanks to stronger gains in 2023, 2024, and 2025, when it has been the top performer so far.

During this time, AVLV’s volatility has been in line with the Russell 1000, with a 3-year beta of 1.00. Meanwhile, all peers have betas below 1.00, with funds like VTV and MGV exhibiting betas at 0.77 and 0.80, respectively, as peers in general have had a much more defensive sector mix, with heavier allocations to healthcare, consumer staples, and utilities. A point of concern is AVLV’s 3-year downside capture ratio of 128, which is much higher than the Russell 1000 (105) and also most peers, which have been in the 102-121 range. As we can see, MGV’s downside capture of 102 indicates that mega caps have seen more moderate declines during selloffs. On the other hand, other funds, especially RPV, have seen higher readings driven by their heavier exposure to mid and small caps, which are typically more vulnerable to declines during adverse market conditions like 2022.

With an average daily trading value of about $37.0 million, AVLV is a liquid fund, though it is still a long way from heavy-volume peers VTV and IWD, both north of $800 million a day. That helps explain AVLV’s 0.07% bid-ask spread, which can not be compared with most funds, all in the 0.01%-0.03% range. The fund’s 5% turnover is the lowest in the group, highlighting its longer-term investment horizon, though peers like VTV, SCHV, and MGV have shown turnover below 10%. Its expense rate of 0.15% is just above the peer group’s average, reflecting relatively low costs in the whole value ETF space. The fund offers a 1.25% dividend yield, which is below the peer group’s 1.93%, driven by its lighter allocation to above-average-yielding sectors, like healthcare, financial services, and utilities. AVLV’s tracking error of above 1.10% highlights its active management profile, while most peers track benchmark indexes. Finally, the fund’s 3-year Sharpe ratio of 0.83 is well above most peers, only below MGV (0.87), thanks to its outperformance, which more compensates for its higher volatility from a risk-adjusted return perspective.

Final Thoughts

AVLV’s core characteristic is its attempt to offer value to investors without compromising business quality. This strategy helps explain most of the fund’s profile. It holds names like Meta, Apple, and Amazon and remains reasonably diversified, blending value sectors with material allocations to industrials and technology. In the current backdrop, with mixed inflation readings, uncertainties about the impact of AI on companies across the equity market, and elevated expectations for companies’ financial results and guidance, investors appear more cautious during an earnings season that has been marked by volatile performance, especially for mega-cap stocks.

That setup creates a balanced setup for AVLV. If the market becomes more risk-averse and P/E multiples compress, the fund’s discount can help cushion the downside, though not as much as more defensive ETFs in the peer group. On the other hand, the fund’s more balanced sector mix should support performance relative to other value funds if sentiment improves from here. That said, it is reasonable to expect the fund to achieve returns in the range of high-single digit to low-double digit over the next twelve months, assuming S&P 500 earnings growth remains in the mid-teens, as forecast at the beginning of the year by the financial market. If that happens, it would be a strong opportunity for AVLV, as it would build on the strong results already recorded year to date. In conclusion, my take is that AVLV remains a good option for investors seeking balanced value exposure, without falling into deep defensive territory.

data.title: TACK: Sensible Strategy Delivering Some Downside Protection, Yet Weaknesses Exist, A Hold
data.description:
In my view, the Fairlead Tactical Sector ETF (TACK), which has been doing an excellent job this year, beating the iShares Core S&P 500 ETF (IVV) amid the capital rotation, is a good candidate for ETF investors' shortlist if they are on the lookout for dynamic exposures that could protect them from too deep drawdowns during periods of market softness and, at the same time, are content with rather bleak upside capture. However, my point is that TACK is a Hold. I like the concept, yet I am not impressed by the annualized and risk-adjusted returns TACK has delivered since inception in 2022 (that is, they were meaningfully lower than those of IVV).

TACK Strategy And Portfolio

As described on its website, TACK is an actively managed ETF that "seeks capital appreciation with limited drawdowns." As per the summary prospectus, Katie Stockton, CMT, is the portfolio manager.

It is explained that

TACK is a model-driven exchange-traded fund aligned with Fairlead Strategies disciplined technical methodology with a discretionary overlay reserved for market anomalies. The primary goal of the model is to leverage sector leadership, while navigating equity market downdrafts through asset allocation.

The core of the process is technical analysis:

The basis of TACK’s model is technical analysis, with an emphasis on indicators designed to identify long-term trends and major trend reversals. Opportunities are identified using signals from a combination of technical indicators designed to identify price trends, after which a quantitative momentum overlay is applied to finalize the portfolio.

In other words, what I see here is a strategy designed to rotate between certain ETFs (sector ETFs as well as gold and Treasury ETFs enumerated on page 2 of the summary prospectus) and position for risk-on and risk-off scenarios. As to the portfolio composition:

The Fund anticipates holding between 5 and 8 ETF positions, distributed between “risk-on” sector ETF positions of approximately equal sizes and occasional “risk-off” ETF positions of varying sizes based on the results of our technical analysis filters.

The following definitions are given for "risk-on" and "risk-off":

A market where stocks are outperforming bonds is said to be a “risk-on” environment. When stocks are selling off and investors are favoring bonds or gold, the environment is said to be “risk-off.”

What Are TACK's Current Style Factor Exposures?

This is an interesting question, and to answer it, we need to look not at just the portfolio composition but at the aggregate underlying holdings (that is, amalgamate all the equities which are present in the ETFs that TACK is currently long).

So as of February 26, we see eight sector ETFs in the TACK portfolio (so, it is quite obviously in risk-on mode now), with the State Street Energy Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLE) being the top one. In the portfolio, there are also the BBH SWEEP Vehicle and Receivables/Payables (a 0.4% combined net weight).

So how is its factor story different from IVV's? I would like to provide the following table that encapsulates the essentials.

  • TACK's aggregate underlying holdings have around 79.9% weight in IVV, as per my calculations. However, this is just the top of the iceberg as weights of individual stocks are different considerably. For example, the trillion-dollar league has just 14.6% weight in TACK but 36.8% in IVV, in part because the Fairlead ETF currently ignores the financial sector, hence, it has no exposure to Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (BRK.B). So, its 2.4x lower weighted average market cap is the direct consequence of that.
  • Next, I see a considerable value tilt, which is assisted by softer growth characteristics, and slightly weaker quality (not critically, of course, as its allocation to stocks with a B- Quant Profitability grade or higher is only 2.5% weaker than IVV's).
  • Ultimately, TACK has notably larger exposure to low-beta stocks (the weighted average 24-month beta is just 0.86), thanks to its considerable allocation to XLU (while utilities account for only about 2.4% of the IVV portfolio).

TACK Performance

Advantages

First and foremost, TACK has significantly outperformed the iShares Core S&P 500 ETF since the beginning of 2026, which is an achievement worth appreciating given the challenging environment.

Another advantage of TACK is that it does deliver downside protection, though not a perfect one. More specifically, in the fact sheet (as of December 31, 2025), TACK compares its returns to those of the Russell 1000 Equal Weight Index. This index is tracked by the Invesco Russell 1000 Equal Weight ETF (EQAL), which I have covered recently, with a Hold rating assigned.

Now let us look at the data for the April 2022–January 2026 period. In the first case, EQAL is selected as a benchmark.

In the second case, I used IVV as a benchmark. And here, TACK's result looks decent again. As we can see, it captured just 61.8% of IVV's downside. I should also add that its maximum drawdown over the period was -11.30%, which looks much more comfortable than IVV's -20.28%.

Vulnerabilities

The principal vulnerability which I believe TACK has is that it cannot capture a sufficient share of the market's upside (which I usually proxy with an S&P 500 ETF), which, in turn, translates not only into rather soft annualized return but also into unimpressive risk-adjusted returns.

More specifically, since its inception in March 2022, TACK has significantly underperformed IVV. It has also trailed EQAL, though, in fairness, it should be noted that EQAL has raced ahead of it just recently.

Next, over the April 2022–January 2026, TACK delivered risk-adjusted returns (i.e., the Sharpe and Sortino ratios) that were also not particularly impressive compared to those of IVV, although they were stronger than EQAL's.

Bottom Line

In sum, TACK delivers precisely what is promised: "capital appreciation with limited drawdowns." I find the strategy perfectly sensible, and I mostly like how the fund is currently positioned (that is, I would not construct an argument against it).

Still, to me, upside capture is critical, and TACK does not deliver on that front. So, investors who are focused on minimizing drawdowns and are content with the upside capture ratio in the 50s, should shortlist the fund as a possible satellite holding. They should keep in mind that it comes with a rather high expense ratio of 70 bps, which is a significant detractor from total returns. Besides, the median bid/ask spread of 0.1279% (as of February 27) is rather wide. Also, while AUM is considerable at $278.9 million, it is not particularly large, even though the fund has almost four years in the books. All in all, my rating on TACK is Hold.
